Description: Users on the Free tier are limited to 1,000 API requests per day. Requests exceeding this limit will return a 429 Too Many Requests error.
Enterprise workspaces have a dedicated pool of 1,000,000 requests per day with burst handling capabilities up to 500 req/sec.
Admins have full access to billing and workspace settings. 'Members' can create and edit projects. 'Viewers' can only comment and view data. 'Guests' are restricted to specific shared projects.
Data can be exported in CSV, JSON, or XML formats. Exports are generated asynchronously and a download link is emailed. Exports generally complete within 15 minutes.
Slack integration allows real-time notifications for task updates. To configure, go to Settings -> Integrations -> Slack and authorize the bot.
Single Sign-On (SSO) is supported via SAML 2.0. We support Okta, OneLogin, and Azure AD. Enforced SSO can be toggled by the Workspace Owner.
Free accounts are limited to 100MB of file storage per user. Files usually consist of attachments to tasks.
Unlimited file storage is provided. Individual file upload size limit is 5GB.
Audit logs track all user activity including logins, file access, and permission changes. Logs are retained for 7 years to comply with regulatory standards.
Users can add custom fields (Text, Number, Dropdown, Date) to tasks. A maximum of 50 custom fields per project is allowed to ensure performance stability.
Webhooks can be configured to trigger on TaskCreated, TaskUpdated, and TaskDeleted events. The payload is sent as a JSON object to the specified URL.
Support is provided via community forums and email with a response time target of 48 hours. No SLA is provided for free accounts.
24/7 Priority Phone and Email support with a dedicated Customer Success Manager. 1-hour response SLA for critical system outages.
All data is encrypted at rest using AES-256. Data in transit is encrypted via TLS 1.3. Keys are rotated every 90 days.
The mobile app supports offline mode. Changes made offline will sync once the device reconnects to the internet. Conflict resolution uses a 'last-write-wins' strategy.
